clinical_study.brief_title: Point of Care Ultrasound to Confirm Endotracheal Tube Cuff Position in Relationship to the Cricoid in Pediatric Population.

brief_summary.textblock: Anatomically, the infra-glottic area (subglottis) and the cricoid ring are the narrowest part of the larynx. In order to limit the incidence of damage related to mucosal pressure injuries from the presence of an endotracheal tube (ETT), the cuff of the ETT should lie below the cricoid in children. Previously, no clinical or imaging method has been used in real time at the bedside to determine the exact location of the ETT cuff after endotracheal intubation. Point-of-care ultrasound (POCUS) may provide an option for a safe and rapid means of visualizing the cuff of the ETT and its relationship to the cricoid ring in real-time thereby allowing ideal ETT positioning.

detailed_description.textblock: Airway below vocal cords until the distal end of the cricoid referred to as subglottis or infraglottis is considered to be the narrowest part of the airway. An optimal endotracheal tube (ETT) placement with cuffed ETT is to ensure the cuff position below the cricoid ring (cuff free glottis): as well have sufficient distance between ETT tip and carina. Various modalities including clinical examination, ETCO2, imaging (X-ray and ultrasound) are routinely used to verify the position and the tip of the ETT in the airway, however verification of the cuff position remains obscure.

primary_outcome.measure: Visualize the saline-filled cuff of the endotracheal tube
primary_outcome.description: The primary objective was to visualize the saline-filled cuff of the endotracheal tube in relation to the cricoid and tracheal rings

intervention.description: Placing ultrasound on the neck after intubation

study_pop.textblock: 80 children from birth to 7 years, scheduled for the surgery requiring endotracheal intubation

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients undergoing general anesthesia requiring endotracheal intubation
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients with any anatomical airway deformity or mass
